Since  Brex was founded, the majority of our backend code has been written in  Elixir. As our co-founder Pedro explains in  this post, we were largely successful with it as an early stage company. Elixir is an expressive, functional language with great readability and offers strong concurrency control.
 As our  All-in-One Finance platform grows to encompass a larger set of products and services, our workloads and workload orchestration use cases have expanded in complexity and scale.
 Building and maintaining internal libraries to support Elixir as our primary backend language became time consuming, and few other users in the ecosystem seemed to share enough use cases to make OSS collaboration mutually beneficial. As our codebase grew in size, large-scale refactoring became a real problem. While dynamic typing improved velocity when we were younger, as we grew it slowed us down. Due to all these reasons we started looking for a language that gives us most of what we love about Elixir, and address its shortcomings for our use case.
 Programming language selection can be subjective and is often contentious. To make a decision that’s best for our business, we created a comprehensive rubric for evaluating different languages based on the attributes we liked about Elixir and the pain points we experienced.
  Development speed: The future will be great and we want to get there fast. Our choice needs to help us move with urgency and focus. A type-system was a non-negotiable choice here. Languages with first-class support for immutability and functional programming were important. We wanted fast compilers and great developer tooling.
 Learning curve: It should make code easy to write, easy to read and not be too difficult to learn. New engineers should be able to onboard easily.
 Maintainability: Building financial systems means optimizing for the long run and we want our code to be easy to maintain and change. It should be idiomatic and easy to write simpler code that’s thread-safe, maintainable and readable.
 Community, ecosystem and tooling: We’ll serve our customers better if we focus more of our energy on building our All-in-One Finance platform. This is much easier with a community and ecosystem that’s vibrant, inclusive, and growing.
 Scalability: The language needs to scale with our customers as well as with the size of our engineering organization.
  Kotlin did really well on our rubric, and while there are many excellent things about it, we’d like to focus this post more on what drove our decision.
 Type system: We knew that a language with a modern type-system was necessary in scaling our engineering codebase as well as organization. Language features like type inference,  null safety, sealed classes, enum classes, data classes, etc. make it really a compelling choice as a type-system. Despite the powerful feature set, the Kotlin compiler is blazing fast. The IntelliJ integration makes navigating, reading and writing code in large codebases extremely productive. Most importantly, while the language includes a modern, powerful type-system it’s fairly easy to learn and use.
 Ecosystem: Thanks to the incredible ecosystem around Kotlin and more broadly the JVM, we’re able to stand on the shoulders of giants. We found the community to be extremely friendly, inclusive and fast-growing. Kotlin interop with Java makes it really simple to leverage a lot of code written for Java. Reusing battle-tested solutions leaves us with more time to build Brex’s All-in-One Finance tool for businesses.
 Modern language features: Kotlin as a language is concise, expressive and easy to learn. Functional programming in Kotlin offers advanced options, yet doesn’t have a steep learning curve. It offers first-class support for immutability including a standard library for immutable collections
 Performance: There’s a lot of evidence of high-scale, performant systems built on top of the JVM. While backend development on Kotlin is relatively new, most of the underlying frameworks we use have been battle tested (gRPC, netty, JDBC access layers). In most cases, the bytecode generated is quite similar to what Java would generate, so this increases our confidence. Additionally, Kotlin coroutines offer great concurrency control and make it simple to write asynchronous code without callback hell.
  For all the reasons stated above and much more, it was clearly a strong candidate. That said, we still wanted to validate the stated claims ourselves, and, more importantly, convince engineers to adopt Kotlin. Any sufficiently complex technology challenge has large technical and people problems to solve. A large percentage of engineers at Brex enjoyed working in Elixir. While we all agreed that it was not the best fit for our future, it was a high bar that Kotlin had to meet.
 We initially prototyped by trying to rewrite an existing service in Kotlin. This service was reasonably small and a good candidate for a typical service at Brex. It covered enough ground that a prototype would give us early validation.
 Our technical strategy for picking framework and library choices was driven by longevity. We want to bet on things that are used by industry peers and are less likely to become obsolete. A few days of obsessing over the right choice could save us months or years of efforts in the future. It goes without saying that what we define as good was based on our evaluation rubric. What works for us may not work for others and it may not work for us in the future either.
 We’d sleep better and engender confidence in our choices knowing that we used all information known to us at the time. We felt strongly about optimizing for internal consistency and maintaining high engineering mobility across Kotlin services. Internal consistency cultivates shared and decentralized expertise across teams.
 We spent most of the time gluing together our ideal choices and evaluating different technology choices. Our primary criteria for each decision was to see adoption and popularity, but most importantly, we wanted to see if there was evidence of investment by large engineering organizations.
 Some choices looked great and would work well for small projects but lacked evidence that they could scale to large codebases and systems. Some others would make it difficult to write idiomatic Kotlin code. We didn’t want our code to look awkward and necessitate conflicting mental models. We’ll try to present a mile-high view of where we’re at today and we hope to dive deeper into them in future posts.
 Our code lives in a monorepo, and while gradle would’ve been an easier choice to start with, we weren’t convinced that it would scale for a monorepo with complex dependency graphs. Fortunately bazel was already in use at Brex and we use  rules_kotlin for building and testing Kotlin targets. We use  rules_jvm_external for external dependency management to prevent the terrifying  diamond dependency problem on the JVM. Of all our choices, bazel was the one with the steepest learning curve that some engineers struggled with the most. But we love the fast, hermetic and scalable build system and think it’s the best long term solution.
 Our backend consists of microservices that communicate over gRPC with protobuf as our interchange format. For asynchronous communication, we use an internal pub-sub system that’s built on top of Kafka. We use  Micronaut to build these microservices, event consumers, HTTP servers and cron workloads. We like to think of Micronaut and its dependency injection framework as the glue that composes our services.
 The aspect oriented programming from Micronaut is powerful, but some found it to have a steeper learning curve. Since this isn’t a common setup, we had to add support to add the micronaut plugins to work with bazel. Services built using micronaut have a low startup time and low memory overhead, which we found really impressive. We use  grpc-kotlin for writing gRPC services and clients. The support for coroutines is great, however, the generated protobuf bindings are Java-based and we don’t get to reap the full benefits of the Kotlin language. We think this is an acceptable compromise until there’s an  official Kotlin protobuf API.
 Most services use PostgreSQL as the persistence layer. We found the  Exposed framework to be a delightful choice. The exposed DSL demonstrates the power of Kotlin in writing type-safe SQL operations. The framework is new and rapidly gaining adoption but the documentation discoverability could be better. We run our database migrations with  flyway and use  testcontainers for testing database interactions.
 We found the JVM observability ecosystem to be the most mature that’s out there. It was seamless to add these integrations using Micronaut. We use  opentracing for distributed tracing and  micrometer for collecting metrics. We use  KotlinLogging backed with  logback as the backend. We found integrations with our existing observability stack which uses Datadog and Sentry to be very straightforward.
 We picked  kotest and  mockk for writing tests. Much like the exposed framework, the kotest DSL really bring out the best of the Kotlin language features and it provides a powerful, yet simple way to write tests that are expressive and beautiful.
 There are many general purpose libraries that we’re in use but in particular we’re really happy with our usages of  Arrow and  Guava.
  After our prototype, we felt pretty optimistic about the future of Kotlin and we wanted to move forward with it. We wanted to stagger the rollout of how Kotlin would be adopted at Brex and we solicited multiple teams who were interested in being early adopters. Additionally, at our internal Hackathon we encouraged teams to build using Kotlin by carving a special award for it.
 Initial feedback was pretty positive but there were some parts that needed refinement and would frustrate people. We quickly realized that any warts would amplify and replicate across multiple services. It was important we get ahead of them because if left unaddressed they’d have an outsized impact. We took the following multi-pronged approach to get ahead of this by adding:
  We are big believers in a  written culture and it’s particularly important as we’re a  remote-first company. Written documentation is an extremely scalable and effective way to communicate in large groups.
 We wrote internal guides on everything from setting up your local environment, education resources, setting up servers, clients, databases and much more. This was written as a wiki encouraging folks to read it and keep things updated. Fairly often, we’d encounter a case not seen before at Brex and we use these opportunities to improve it for posterity. Lastly, it’s extremely important to note that incorrect and obsolete technical documentation is documentation debt and documentation debt is technical debt.
  It was difficult to correctly set up a new service especially for new engineers. We added a scaffolding workflow in  backstage — an open-source developer platform by Spotify that we use for developer workflows. This made onboarding new services much smoother especially since most people building services hadn’t worked with our new technical stack.
  We still found the need for some core libraries to be written that served as the glue and in some cases replicated missing functionality. We also had a class of libraries that simplified building services. As an example, Micronaut is typically configured using YAML files but since a lot of services across Brex share very similar configuration there was a lot of duplicated and critical configuration. Additionally YAML isn’t type safe and it’s very easy to make errors with it. We built a small layer to programmatically generate property sources using a much smaller set of configuration.
 Above all, it was critical for us to be extremely responsive and receptive to the feedback from our early adopters.
  Since ironing out the major kinks with the early adopters, every new backend service since has been written in Kotlin. Today, engineers new to Kotlin can get ramped up very quickly and we’re able to move a lot faster with higher confidence. Our Kotlin codebase is growing and there’s a lot of work ahead of us. We’re glad to be part of the growing set of engineers across the globe who build software using Kotlin.  Come join us in building Brex’s All-in-One Finance for businesses.

Jump to navigation  Jump to search  This is a  list of U.S. states and territories by  carbon dioxide emissions due to human activity. The data presented below are energy-related greenhouse emissions (CO 2 equivalent) only, published by the  U.S. Energy Information Administration (2017 data). These data do not include emissions from other activity such as agriculture, industrial processes, or waste management.  [1]  [2]
 The  Northern Mariana Islands is not ranked in the table below because there is no data for that territory.  [note 1] The Northern Mariana Islands is the only state/territory with no carbon dioxide emissions data.
 The jurisdiction with the highest total carbon dioxide emissions is  Texas, and the jurisdiction with the lowest total carbon dioxide emissions is  American Samoa. The region with the highest per capita carbon dioxide emissions is  Wyoming, and the jurisdiction with the lowest per capita carbon dioxide emissions is the  District of Columbia.
   
 Source for territories (population): CIA World Factbook (2017 web.archive.org captures) for 2017 populations,  [4]  [note 9] plus 2019 versions of the CIA World Factbook which contain 2017 carbon dioxide data for four of the five territories  [5]  [6]  [7]  [8]
     The 'States and D.C. Total' value represents the sum of    CO  2 emissions from the 50 U.S. states plus the District of Columbia. This value differs from total U.S. CO 2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion reported in the  Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks. The U.S. inventory value is larger because it includes emissions from U.S. territories and possessions; it also uses a different approach for estimating emissions from non-energy uses of fossil fuels (which are not included in the combustion-related values shown in this table).
 Nationally, CO 2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion represented the largest source (76%) of total  GWP–weighted emissions from all emission sources in 2014.  [2] Similarly, CO 2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion are the largest source of greenhouse gas emissions within a state.  [2]
 Numbers for territories include only fossil fuel numbers — they do not include petroleum, natural gas, and coal numbers.
